reviews.review_msg: Shows up late and leaves again for a long time...

Laycock is a very intelligent professor. Class isn't mandatory however the lectures correspond with the readings which help with understanding the material, and the tests and paper are related to what's discussed. Tutorials are basically mandatory since they count for a lot

Meh. Too lazy to properly implement online learning that was forced due to COVID-19. Instead made us watch 2019 lectures so he didnt have to do extra work. Did not make things easier and showed no compassion in light of the stress caused by covid, like every other prof had done. probably time to retire old man (couldn't use a microphone!)

Professor Laycock is extremely knowledgeable in political philosophy. The problem though is how he teaches it. Yes the material itself can get pretty dry and boring, but that is when profs become creative to keep the classes attention, and he fails to do it. His slides are just paragraphs that he expands on verbally, and he makes it so dry
ego centric. Knows his stuff, but also makes sure you know that he knows it all and you don't.

DO NOT TAKE POL 210 WITH THIS PROF arrogant, not up to date with his teaching, terrible slides. 20 minute YouTube crash courses on whichever philosopher is being taught includes nearly the same amount of information as he teaches in his 2 hours class. Tutorials are useless but mandatory as it counts for 20%. DO NOT TAKE POL 210 WITH THIS PROF

David is great. Lectures are a bit dry but you can tell it's because the subject material is boring, not because he is. Clear assignments and expectations. He wants you to succeed, and as long as you put in considerable effort, you will. Don't expect an easy A though. Super smart guy, mad respect for him.

Laycock clearly knows his stuff. He seems capable of answering any question. The only problem is that this class has not be revised to accommodate the average student. There is an absurd amount of material in this class, to the point where lecture material spills into the first half of the midterm class. Hundreds of pages of readings a week. ..

SoooooOOOoooooo much writing..... Final exam has six "short answer" questions that are 1.5 pages each, AND an 8-10 page essay, 3 hours and no take home. Nice prof but ridiculous test workload. So much reading but that's just the nature of the course. Tough grader and he grades the midterm and final.
He knows the material very well but he doesn't know how to transfer them. lecture were horrible exam are tough

I did enjoy taking POL210 with Laycock: he is very knowledgeable and passionate about political philosophy, and his lectures are consistently interesting. That being said, there is A LOT of reading in this course (easily more than 500 pages worth) that is absolutely necessary to the tests and tutorials. If you're not a fan of reading, stay away!

By far the most knowledgeable prof in the Poli Sci department, and wise in a grandfatherly way. He has a wealth of knowledge about a variety of topics and he does not have an overt bias which is refreshing. If you want to understand political theory take his classes, but be prepared to work hard and read a lot. Highly recommended.

Want a real teacher in poli sci? Take Laycock. He knows Canadian Party politics and ideologies like few others. Be prepared though, expectations are high and your participation grade is essential if you want a good mark. You must do the readings otherwise you will get a bad mark on the final as well as participation.

Took both 313 and 428 in the same semester... Probably not the brightest idea I ever had. I'd take the classes again but I'd opt to split them up. I learned a fair bit in his classes. The discussions in 428 would have been better if more people read the textbook though. His grading system is VERY arbitrary, I'll take my B's and be thankful.
Great prof! Anyone criticizing his approach towards students must not have even attempted to speak to the man!

David Laycock is by far the most knowledgable professor when it comes to Political science at SFU. POL 428 is a great class, but you have to engage. And do the readings or this class will be very challenging. Laycock is helpful and will help you if you ask. I would definitely take another class with him.

Very interesting but not an easy course. However, if you manage to read the materials it becomes actually very interesting and useful. I took this course for my exchange at SFU and I found David a very helpful Professor who is actually interested in the student itself and not just the number!

Tough subject, dry at times but if you put the effort into the readings you can get a lot out of the class. He's always ready to help you whether on an essay or a question about the class. Good solid prof

Best professor ever. If you don't have a strong grasp on analytical/critical thinking and normative theory isn't your thing- don't take this class since it won't be an easy A. However, the amount you learn is incredible and he takes great interest in the course topics. He's also always eager to help clarify things.
This Prof is boring. I guess its the subject, but i barely could remember what i learned. Wikipedia and other sites made me me pass this class. His marking is fair but rigid!

One of the best, in large part because of his sheer wealth of knowledge: if you have a question, David has an answer. He does expect a fair bit of reading (and you actually have to do it), but it encourages good discussion, and hey, that's political theory.

Best Professor I have ever had.  Almost gave up on SFU before this class. Professor Laycock is a wealth of knowledge, and amazingly open to help students.  Nobody has affected by education more than Professor Laycock.  That being said, he expects engaged students.

Once he figured out how to structure his lectures, the amount of information he can pack into them in amazing. One of my favourite classes if nothing else because discussion is kept at a high standard. Would strongly recommend.

Everyone bashing David here did poorly in his class. Lame way to judge a prof, don't u think? This guy is my all time favourite professor - show an ounce of interest and he will help your academic career move forward at a rate you can't imagine. Very great guy. Got a C- in 210, pulled my socks up and got As in the other 3 courswes I took with him.
This prof is a bit of a bore. Also rigid marker and kind of a weasel. Class was mildly interesting, but wouldn't recommend.
No Comments
Works to his own agenda: either you can forward this man's relentless march up the career pole - or you are out!
This prof shows great favoritizm to male students and only if you are 4.0 student. Very self serving and very ego centric, and a back stabbing sob.

A good character is the best feature of Laycock. Everything else - watch out. He is a hard, merciless marker. He assigns an extremely heavy amount of readings, and he expects participation and ideas. Overall, I tried hard, but barely passed the class.

David has an excellent base knowledge in Poli Sci and Political Theory, I really do wish he could keep my attention longer.  First time I ever fell asleep in a lecture was listening to him.  He is a good prof and you can learn a lot from him and his lectures, but bring caffeine pills to class if you want to appreciate his content.
one of the most dedicated profs I have ever had. his courses are challenging, but ultimately very worthwhile.
Detailed lectures, but unstructured and boring. Difficult marker

Normative theory par excellance. I had the chance to re re read his introduction to a collection of essays pertaining to democratic theory. Miffed was I at the clever boldness which which he pens his thoughts. It is only a matter of time before he publishes a book which is sure surely capture the CB Macpherson award for outstanding theory.
This had to have been the most boring class I have ever had at sfu. He assigned to much material to read. Someone should tell him to put together course ware packs.

His sense of humor is pleasent, his punch lines are so subtle that I am not at all surprised that only a few students pick up on them. I pray to liken him to a dentist, and his most painful.... wait a minute no dental tool can hurt ones gums as much as freeden hurt ones brain.

Definitely knows his stuff. Easy-going, lectures can be a bit dry (but then, this was a political theory class), but he explains things well and his emailed follow-along notes are a nice bonus. My opinion of him has improved since taking 210 with him a couple years ago.
way to be laycock. caring, funny, overall good person.
This guy is very insensitive if he finds that you are not picking up on his ideas which are often obscured and lacks clarity.  A very contentious professor.
Doesn't give a crap about students. Bad teacher.  But still pulled off an A-
Very smart, but very boring, he managed to stretch a  How do you do  intro class to over an hour.

Lectures are a bit dry, but he emails all the lecture notes to the class ahead of time so you can just follow along and make the occasional note, which is fantastic. Pretty laid back. Course material is very useful for polisci majors.
Sometimes a bit boring in class but very intelligent and helpful if you see him after class.  Tonnes of reading and great dialogue.  Tough marker but obviously cares immensely.
Detailed, careful, and interesting.
Very friendly, cute in a fatherly professor way and quite helpful if YOU ASK. Classes are very hard.
You have 2 hours to check out all the cutties in the class. Time well wasted...
He wanders
